title: New DVD releases: 'Tomorrowland,' 'Dope,' 'San Andreas,' 'The Gallows'
text:
New DVD releases: 'Tomorrowland,' 'Dope,' 'San Andreas,' 'The Gallows' TNS Casey (Britt Robertson) in Disney’s “Tomorrowland.” By Chris Foran of the Journal Sentinel Oct. 13, 2015 7:00 a.m. (0) Comments DUE OUT TUESDAY 
TOMORROWLAND (Disney) After finding a gateway to a different place in space and time where the hopeful version of the future has come alive, a brilliant teenager joins forces with a disillusioned former boy genius to save that world. Disney adventure with George Clooney, Britt Robertson, Hugh Laurie. (PG; violence, thematic elements, language) 
DOPE (Universal) A college-bound teenager, in pursuit of some street cred and the girl he's got a crush on, goes to a party at an underground club and winds up with a huge stash of drugs he now has to unload. High-energy comedy written and directed by Rick Famuyiwa, with Shameik Moore, Tony Revolori, Kiersey Clemons, Zoe Kravitz, A$AP Rocky. (R; language, drug content, sexuality and nudity, some violence) 
SAN ANDREAS (Warner) The Big One finally hits California, and helicopter rescue pilot Dwayne Johnson is on the job. Effects-filled earthquake disaster movie co-stars Carla Gugino, Ioan Gruffudd, Paul Giamatti. (PG-13; pervasive disaster/mayhem scenes, brief language) 
THE GALLOWS (Warner) High school students go to the scene of a tragedy — years earlier, a student died in an accident involving a prop noose during the rehearsal of a play called "The Gallows" — and unwittingly revive the evil spirit still lurking there. Found-footage-style horror from the "Paranormal Activity" folks. (R; violence, gore) 
THE LITTLE DEATH (Virgil) Raunchy Australian sex comedy about five suburban couples struggling to keep their sex lives from getting stale. (Not rated; pervasive language, sex and nudity) 
SKIN TRAFFIK (Alchemy) A hit man on what he believes is his last job finds himself in everyone else's sights. Violent action movie with Gary Daniels, Mickey Rourke, Eric Roberts, Daryl Hannah, Michael Madsen. (R; pervasive violence, sexual material, language, some drug content) 
BALLET BOYS (First Run) Documentary follows three male friends' four-year quest to become ballet stars. In Norwegian with English subtitles. (Not rated) 
A RIVER BETWEEN US (Virgil) Documentary chronicles the efforts to save Oregon's Klamath River, reportedly the largest river restoration project in American history. (Not rated) COMING SOON 
OCT. 20 
JURASSIC WORLD (Universal), PAPER TOWNS (Fox), TESTAMENT OF YOUTH (Sony), THE VATICAN TAPES (Lionsgate), THE WOLFPACK (Magnolia), Z FOR ZACHARIAH (Lionsgate), DRAGON BALL Z: RESURRECTION 'F' (Funimation), HUNGRY HEARTS (IFC), NORTHERN LIMIT LINE (Well Go USA), SHORT SKIN (Breaking Glass), I SPIT ON YOUR GRAVE 3 (Anchor Bay) 
OCT. 27 
THE GIFT (Universal), SOUTHPAW (Anchor Bay), PIXELS (Sony), MAX (Warner), A LITTLE CHRISTMAS (Breaking Glass), THE HUMAN CENTIPEDE III: THE FINAL SEQUENCE (Shout! Factory) RECENTLY RELEASED 
AVENGERS: AGE OF ULTRON Plans to protect the world lead Tony Stark (a.k.a. Iron Man) to revive a dormant artificial-intelligence program designed to keep the peace — only the system declares war on the Avengers, and humanity, instead. The world's mightiest heroes — Iron Man (Robert Downey Jr.), Bruce Banner/The Hulk (Kenosha native Mark Ruffalo), Captain America (Chris Evans), the Norse god Thor (Chris Hemsworth), Black Widow (Scarlett Johansson) and Hawkeye (Jeremy Renner) — face off against the title bad guy, voiced by James Spader. With Elizabeth Olsen, Aaron Taylor-Johnson, Samuel L. Jackson, Paul Bettany. (PG-13; violence, mayhem, some suggestive comments) 
MAGIC MIKE XXL Three years after he retired from stripping, Magic Mike (Channing Tatum) gets back into the game to join some of his old pals at a stripper convention at Myrtle Beach. Sequel to the 2012 smarter-than-expected beefcake hit brings back some of the original cast (yes, Matt Bomer and Joe Manganiello; no, Matthew McConaughey) and adds some new, um, faces, including Michael Strahan, Donald Glover. (R; strong sexual content, some nudity, drug use, pervasive language) 
ME AND EARL AND THE DYING GIRL A high school senior, who'd rather spend his days making bad movies with his friend, is forced to spend time with a classmate who's just been diagnosed with leukemia. Sundance Film Festival award-winning indie comedy (PG-13; sexual content, drug material, language, mature themes) 
INSIDIOUS CHAPTER 3 Suspense-driven horror prequel, centered on the psychic who in the first two movies helped a family battle evil. With Lin Shaye. (PG-13; violence, frightening images, some language, mature themes) 
WHEN MARNIE WAS THERE A lonely girl moves to the seaside and meets a woman with a secret. Animation from Japan's famed Studio Ghibli, with voices by Hailee Steinfeld, Kiernan Shipka, John C. Reilly, Vanessa L. Williams, Geena Davis, Kathy Bates. (PG; mature themes, smoking) 
DARK PLACES Three decades after her mother and two sisters are murdered — and her young brother is sent to prison for the killings — a woman still trying to shake her family's dark past is tracked down by a group of amateur sleuths convinced her brother is innocent. Thriller based on a novel by "Gone Girl" author Gillian Flynn, with Charlize Theron, Nicholas Hoult. (R; some violence, language, drug use, sexual content) 
GOING CLEAR: SCIENTOLOGY AND THE PRISON OF BELIEF Documentary by Alex Gibney ("Taxi to the Dark Side," "Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence in the House of God") takes a deep dive into the Church of Scientology and its discontents. Based on the nonfiction bestseller. (Not rated) 
BATKID BEGINS Documentary recounts how the wish of a boy with leukemia — to be Batman — turned into a crowdsourced phenomenon. (PG; some thematic material) 
ESCOBAR: PARADISE LOST An American surfer dude goes to Colombia and falls in love with a girl who turns out to be the niece of drug kingpin Pablo Escobar — who'd like him to join the family business. With Josh Hutcherson, Benicio Del Toro. (R; violence, gore) 
Compiled by Chris Foran © 2015 , Journal Sentinel Inc. All rights reserved. About Chris Foran 
Chris Foran is an assistant entertainment editor, overseeing the Tap Weekend, Tap Daily, Good Morning and TV Cue sections. He also writes about movies, books, pop culture and fun stuff to do in Milwaukee.
